posts.title: Replays, VODs, and Congratulations for the 2015 Global Finals
posts.title_plain: Replays, VODs, and Congratulations for the 2015 Global Finals
posts.content:
The StarCraft II 2015 World Championship Series was as good as you can ask for. Going all the way to the final game 7, sOs and Life pushed their skills to the limit, constantly outthinking and out maneuvering each other. The two former champions played at the top of their game and are both well deserving of the title, ‘world champion’, but there can only be one in 2015! Congratulations to sOs, who takes his second WCS title.

WCS Finals VODs

___________________________________________________________________

WCS Finals Replays

posts.title: The WCS Global Finals Continue Friday
posts.title_plain: The WCS Global Finals Continue Friday
posts.content:
The WCS Global Finals are starting to heat up! Last weekend, eight challengers were eliminated from the original bracket of sixteen. On November 6 and 7 at BlizzCon 2015, we’ll watch as the remaining finalists duke it out to determine who claims the title of 2015 WCS Global Champion and a $100,000 prize!

To make sure you don’t miss a second of the upcoming action-packed weekend, we’ve rounded up all the info you might need below. Whether you’re watching live at BlizzCon or from the comfort of home at StarCraft2.com/WCS, you’ll definitely want to keep the below details in mind.

The Schedule
The quarter finals at BlizzCon begin Friday, November 6 at noon. The semi finals take place the next day, while the finals themselves start at 4:00 p.m. PST on Saturday, November 7. Each match is single-elimination, with the quarter finals and semi-finals as best-of-five and the finals as best-of-seven.

The Resources
Don’t forget to check out the brackets and standings before the show, and find a local BarCraft so you can watch the game with friends (and hopefully snag some BarCraft Boost loot)!

The Streams
We’re working with our global partners to bring you tournament coverage in multiple languages. Check out our BlizzCon guide on where to watch the World Championship Series for the complete list.

Eight competitors, but only one can take the championship! Who will it be? Get ready to tune in and find out as the 2015 WCS Global Finals come to a close at BlizzCon!

On November 6 and 7 at BlizzCon 2015, we’ll watch as the remaining finalists duke it out to determine who claims the title of 2015 WCS Global Champion and a $100,000 prize! To make [...]

posts.title: WCS Global Finals Start Today!
posts.content:
It’s time for the WCS Global Finals as another year of StarCraft II competition comes to a close. Not only are players completing for first place and $250,000 in prizes, they are competing to be the final Heart of the Swarm Global Champion.

For a full rundown of the top 16, check out the WCS site to see all the player profiles and standings. The Global Finals will start at Opening Week in Burbank, CA on November 1 and will conclude at Blizzcon in Anaheim, CA on November 6 & 7. Do not miss a minute of the event brought to you by our very talented line up of Casters and Hosts.

Opening Week Broadcasting Team

  • Chobra
  • Apollo
  • TLO
  • iNcontroL
  • Nathanias
  • Rotterdam
  • Kaelaris*
  • ToD*

*Kaelaris and ToD will only join the WCS crew to cast Opening Week, and will provide their expertise to the Heroes of the Storm broadcast at November 6 & 7.

Joining us at BlizzCon

  • Day[9]
  • Artosis
  • Tasteless
  • Maynarde
  • Moonglade

Be sure to head over to the official Blizzcon Website to check out the full schedule and where you can find links to all of the official streams. Be sure to not miss the full information and the brackets as well.

Also, if you missed it, make sure to read up on our Legacy of the Void Archon Mode exhibitions, Legends and Champions, on November 6.

posts.title: Prepare to Watch the WCS Finals With a BarCraft Boost!
posts.title_plain: Prepare to Watch the WCS Finals With a BarCraft Boost!
posts.content:
The StarCraft II WCS Season 3 Global Finals will wrap up at BlizzCon! If you’re organizing a BarCraft to watch the event, you’re in luck: we’re randomly selecting 58 hosts to receive a BarCraft Boost to power up their viewing party!*

Each BarCraft Boost will include some great StarCraft-themed items to give out to your attendees during your viewing party, including lanyards, figures, keychains, and a set of StarCraft coasters that make a perfect place to set your frosty beverages. No matter how you watch, you’ll be all set to go.

So Who’s Eligible?
Anyone who wants to run a StarCraft II BarCraft is eligible to receive a box. Whether this is your first or fifteenth BarCraft, we want to help make your WCS Premier League Finals event a success!

How to Submit
Entering is easy! Just fill out the BarCraft Event Submission form here to let us know if your event needs a Boost Package. Be sure to submit your event by the cutoff time of 11:59 p.m. PDT on October 25.

First Time Hosting?
If this is your first time hosting a BarCraft, please check out our BarCraft Event Guidelines.

Don’t forget that everyone can watch the StarCraft II World Championship Series for free at the official World Championship Series Portal site.

* For full rules and eligibility requirements, see this post.

posts.title: WCS Global Finals – FanTaSy vs. HyuN Tiebreaker
posts.title_plain: WCS Global Finals – FanTaSy vs. HyuN Tiebreaker
posts.content:
For the second time in two years, we have a tie in the WCS Standings across the 16th place cutoff! HyuN and FanTaSy both finished their 2015 season with 3025 points in the WCS Standings. The match to determine the 16th Global Finals player will be live in the FreecUP Studio (old GSL Studio) in Seoul, South Korea at 2:30 am PDT on October 6.

The tiebreaker will be a Best-of-5 on the Season 3 map pool. The broadcasts will be available in free HD on Afreeca.tv (KR, EN) and Twitch.tv (EN). The match will be commentated by Dan “Artosis” Stemkoski and Nick “Tasteless” Plott. The winner will advance to the WCS 2015 Global Finals at BlizzCon, Nov 1 and 6-7.

We hope you enjoy this exciting conclusion the 2015 WCS Standings race! Make sure to tune in on StarCraft2.com/WCS.

posts.title: The Biggest Surprises of WCS 2015
posts.content:
If you didn’t read my previous articles, these stats are calculated by WCS Predictor, which simulates every match in every tournament that gives WCS Points millions of times. Blizzcon Chances are the chances to qualify in the top 16 for Blizzcon, as rated by WCS Predictor.

Tied at DreamHack

At DreamHack Stockholm, in the round of 16, we had Fantasy vs Hyun. Both players flew to the event to pick up their last WCS Points and secure their Blizzcon Chances.

If Fantasy lost then he would be knocked down to just 36.09% Blizzcon Chances; if Fantasy lost and Dark had won his match, then Fantasy would’ve been down to 0%. If Hyun lost then he’d have been knocked down to 0% as he needed at least a 2nd place. Hyun getting a 2nd place would tie him with Fantasy, but Dark could still pass them, and a 1st place would’ve put Hyun at 100%.

People have been counting out Hyun all year long, saying he only made it previously by competing in the easier WCS America. He made the SSL round of 16 twice this year, but still most of his points came from strong performances in international tournaments.

Then Hyun defeated Fantasy 2-0, showing how much he wanted to make to Blizzcon. Dark lost to Leenock, and sOs beat Harstem, meaning only Fantasy and Hyun had uncertain Blizzcon Chances.

Against Rain, again people counted out Hyun, until he won 3-1. Hyun was facing Reality in the semifinals. Fantasy knew that Hyun would tie him with a 2nd place, and knock him out of the WCS Global Finals if he got 1st place. Hyun again won 3-1.

Hyun’s killing spree was ended in the finals by Solar with a 3-1 score.

Now both Hyun and Fantasy can only practice as hype builds for their tie breaker match to determine who goes to the WCS Global Finals and who watches from home.

WCS Global Finals Bracket

Here is how the bracket looks showing all the possible players for each slot.

The winner of the Hyun vs Fantasy tie breaker will face herO.

The GSL finals between Innovation and Byul determines the rest.

If Byul beats Innovation, then Byul faces Lilbow, Innovation faces Classic, and Life faces Zest.

If Innovation beats Byul, then Byul faces Classic, Innovation faces Zest, and Life faces Lilbow.

Innovation is currently 27-14 in WCS matches this year; 9-3 vs Zerg, 7-4 vs Terran, and 11-7 vs Protoss; making his vs Zerg his strongest matchup as usual.

Byul is currently 24-9 in WCS matches this year; with an incredible 8-1 vs Terran, 4-2 vs Zerg, and 12-6 vs Protoss; making his vs Terran his strongest matchup.

This is also a rematch from the SSL quarterfinals on August 20th where Byul kept his composure to barely win 3-2 over Innovation’s mech on Terraform.

WCS Year Recap

Biggest surprise qualifications of this WCS year

#1 Dream started the WCS year at 3.06%. His lowest point in season 1 was 1.7% on December 9th. His lowest point in season 2 was 78.44% on April 7th. He hit 100% in season 2 after he made his second consecutive SSL finals by beating herO in the semifinals on June 4th.

#2 Hydra started at 9.25%. His lowest point in season 1 was 7.32% on December 8th. In season 2 it was 64.11% on April 14th. He hit 100% in season 2 when he baat Lilbow in the WCS finals on June 28th.

#3 Byul started at 10.64%. His lowest point in season 1 was 1.09% on January 30th. In season 2 it was 8.69% on April 9th. In season iy was 80.86% on June 29th. Byul hit 100% when he beat TY in the SSL Season 3 semifinals on September 3rd.

#4 Lilbow started at 11.52%. His lowest point in season 1 was 1.1% on April 5th. In season 2 it was 0.32% on April 14th just before qualifying for WCS. In season 3 it was 9.23% on July 11th. Lilbow hit 100% after he beat Mana in the WCS Season 3 finals on September 13th and Rogue and Gumiho were defeated in GSL.

#5 Rogue started at 14.81%. His lowest point in season 1 was 11.84% on November 30th. In season 2 it was 42.67% on April 11th. In season 3 it was 62.21% on August 2nd. Rogue hit 100% on September 24th after Byul beat Dear in the GSL semifinals and the DreamHack Stockholm bracket was drawn.

#6 Classic started at 20.70%. His lowest point in season 1 was 1.60% on March 15th. In season 2 it was 7.60% on April 7th. In season 3 it was 99.69% on July 3rd. Classic hit 100% after he beat Parting in the IEM Shenzhen finals on July 19th.

#7 Maru started at 21.27%. His lowest point in season 1 was 19.42% on December 9th. Maru hit 100% after he beat Dream in the SSL Season 1 finals on March 21st.

#8 Life started at 27.60%. His lowest point in season 1 was 27.60% on November 17th. Life hit 100% after he beat Parting in the GSL Season 1 finals on March 22nd.

#9 Polt started at 30.95%. His lowest point in season 1 was 13.76% on January 14th. In season 2 it was 89.59% on June 25th. In season 3 it was 97.39% on July 17th. Polt hit 100% after he advanced from the WCS Season 3 round of 16.

#10 sOs started at 31.86%. His lowest point in season 1 was 15.37% on March 3rd. In season 2 it was 17.32% on May 19th. In season 3 it was 20.99% on August 1st. sOs hit 100% after he advanced to the DreamHack Stockholm round of 16 and Fantasy was eliminated on September 24th.

#11 INnoVation started at 38.12%. His lowest point in season 1 was 38.12% on November 17th. In season 2 it was 21.64% on June 24th. In season 3 it was 31.73% on July 1st. Innovation hit 100% after he advanced from the GSL Season 3 round of 16 on September 11th.

#12 Zest started at 39.82%. His lowest point in season 1 was 8.28% on March 9th. In season 2 it was 65.78% on April 6th. In season 3 it was 74.66% on June 29th. Zest hit 100% after several players were eliminated in the WCS Season 3 round of 16 on September 10th.

#13 Rain started at 41.37%. His lowest point in season 1 was 35.47% on March 26th. In season 2 it was 43.74% on April 8th. Rain hit 100% after he beat Byul in the GSL Season 2 finals on June 28th.

#14 PartinG started at 43.89%. His lowest point in season 1 was 36.79% on December 9th. In season 2 it was 99.73% on April 9th. Parting hit 100% after he beat Gumiho in the DreamHack Tours finals on May 9th.

#15 herO started at 44.24%. His lowest point in season 1 was 40.71% on November 18th. In season 2 it was 99.95% on April 28th. herO hit 100% after he beat Dear in the KeSPA Cup round of 16 on May 3rd.

Fantasy started the WCS year at 2.92%. His lowest point in season 1 was 1.47% on December 9th. In season 2 it was 25.27% on April 9th. In season 3 it was 23.45% on September 25th, just before Hyun lost the DreamHack Stockholm final to Solar.

Hyun started at 19.48%. His lowest point in season 1 was 3.48% on March 25th. In season 2 it was 5.32% on June 10th. In season 3 it was 2% on September 7th, just before he was confirmed going to DreamHack Stockholm.

Biggest surprise failures of this WCS year

#1 Flash started at 42.79%. His highest point in season 1 was 50.06% on November 19th. In season 2 it was 4.42% on April 10th. In season 3 it was 0.66% on July 25th.

#2 TaeJa started at 37.98%. His highest point in season 1 was 72.12% on December 15th. In season 2 it was 1.61% on April 8th. In season 3 it was 0.01% on July 1st.

#3 Solar started at 31.96%. His highest point in season 1 was 57.35% on December 17th. In season 2 it was 16.76% on April 8th. In season 3 it was 13.84% on August 5th.

#4 Stats started at 29.76%. His highest point in season 1 was 70.26% on February 26th. In season 2 it was 82.65% on June 2nd. In season 3 it was 43.67% on June 29th.

#5 MajOr started at 28.88%. His highest point in season 1 was 35.81% on December 3rd. In season 2 it was 6.96% on April 8th. In season 3 it was 0.45% on June 30th.

#6 soO started at 27.30%. His highest point in season 1 was 29.79% on November 18th. In season 2 it was 24.69% on April 8th. In season 3 it was 19.58% on August 9th.

#7 Scarlett started at 24.43%. Her highest point in season 1 was 31.71% on December 9th. In season 2 it was 0.21% on April 10th. In season 3 it was 0.02% on June 30th.

#8 Bbyong started at 23.38%. His highest point in season 1 was 50.02% on April 2nd. In season 2 it was 47.88% on April 8th. In season 3 it was 6.31% on August 7th.

#9 MMA started at 23.23%. His highest point in season 1 was 46.91% on March 4th. In season 2 it was 22.31% on April 10th. In season 3 it was 1.13% on August 9th.

#10 Cure started at 22.86%. His highest point in season 1 was 32.42% on December 12th. In season 2 it was 4.46% on April 6th. In season 3 it was 0.25% on June 30th.

#11 TY started at 22.77%. His highest point in season 1 was 70.05% on December 19th. In season 2 it was 25.89% on April 8th. In season 3 it was 32.60% on August 20th.

#12 Bomber started at 21.82%. His highest point in season 1 was 40.82% on December 15th. In season 2 it was 12.33% on May 7th. In season 3 it was 1.01% on June 30th.

#13 Jim started at 21.41%. His highest point in season 1 was 21.41% on November 17th. In season 2 it was 0.69% on April 8th. In season 3 it was 0.11% on July 11th.

#14 ForGG started at 20.91%. His highest point in season 1 was 81.26% on January 7th. In season 2 it was 62.73% on May 7th. In season 3 it was 34.50% on September 12th.

#15 San started at 19.33%. His highest point in season 1 was 40.64% on December 17th. In season 2 it was 4.38% on June 28th. In season 3 it was 4.15% on June 29th.

#16 GuMiho started at 19.16%. His highest point in season 1 was 79.76% on December 24th. In season 2 it was 42.19% on May 20th. In season 3 it was 16.84% on September 11th.

#17 Sacsri started at 18.84%. His highest point in season 1 was 20.68% on November 30th. In season 2 it was 6.83% on May 2nd. In season 3 it was 0.48% on July 16th.

#18 YoDa started at 18.72%. His highest point in season 1 was 25.97% on December 9th. In season 2 it was 4.59% on April 8th. In season 3 it was 0.05% on June 30th.

#19 Soulkey started at 18.41%. His highest point in season 1 was 55.28% on April 3rd. In season 2 it was 61.80% on April 13th. In season 3 it was 4.50% on June 30th.

#20 viOLet started at 18.00%. His highest point in season 1 was 18.39% on December 3rd. In season 2 it was 6.74% on April 29th. In season 3 it was 0.57% on July 1st.

In addition to these 20, I’d like to highlight some that didn’t start with the highest chances, but built up to high chances and then failed to qualify.

#22 Dear started at 17.46%. His highest point in season 1 was 64.09% on December 31st. In season 2 it was 34.47% on April 15th. In season 3 it was 23.81% on July 9th.

#27 Bunny started at 12.91%. His highest point in season 1 was 40.84% on April 5th. In season 2 it was 42.82% on June 28th. In season 3 it was 29.16% on July 2nd.

#30 Jaedong started at 12.14%. His highest point in season 1 was 22.93% on December 7th. In season 2 it was 28.78% on June 23rd. In season 3 it was 14.47% on August 23rd.

#35 Leenock started at 9.79%. His highest point in season 1 was 31.24% on January 16th. In season 2 it was 10.40% on April 10th. In season 3 it was 1.36% on June 30th.

#37 Dark started at 9.61%. His highest point in season 1 was 61.29% on March 27th. In season 2 it was 67.26% on June 28th. In season 3 it was 79.44% on August 22nd.

#38 Snute started at 9.51%. His highest point in season 1 was 42.62% on March 11th. In season 2 it was 28.50% on June 28th. In season 3 it was 28.36% on June 29th.

#40 Trap started at 8.77%. His highest point in season 1 was 57.50% on March 27th. In season 2 it was 48.99% on April 10th. In season 3 it was 25.83% on June 29th.

Be sure to check the website for very frequent updates, the FAQ, and the fantasy league WCS Wars!

Also here’s my discussion thread on Team Liquid.

posts.title: WCS 2015 Season 3 Replay Release
posts.content:
Due to the upcoming changes from Patch 3.0 of Heart of the Swarm, the Blizzard eSports team is releasing the Season 3 replays early, prior to the conclusion of the Global StarCraft II League on October 4th. You can find the replays for WCS Premier League Season 3, and most of Season 3 of GSL and SSL below:

WCS 2015 Season 3 Replays

Note: Several WCS Challenger matches are missing, as well as Group E of the WCS Premier League Ro32, due to technical issues. We have also removed all ByuL and INnoVation replays from the download to preserve the integrity of the GSL Finals on October 4th.

posts.title: Last Chances at DreamHack
posts.content:
If you didn’t read my previous articles, these stats are calculated by WCS Predictor which simulates every match in every tournament that gives WCS Points millions of times. Blizzcon Chances are the chances to qualify in the top 16 for Blizzcon, as rated by WCS Predictor.

On Friday we had DreamHack Stockholm complete their player listing, which had some big effects on Blizzcon Chances. Since the last article, we’ve had TY, Stats, and Gumiho all eliminated from the running since they were confirmed to be not attending DreamHack Stockholm. We also had Lilbow securing his spot to Blizzcon.

sOs seems to have learned his lesson from last year when he peaked at 96.65% Blizzcon Chances in early August and still didn’t make it. sOs has an 84.96% chance even if he wins no points from Dreamhack (32nd place or worse), but he decided not to leave it to luck and took it into his own hands by attending. A 16th place here would put sOs up at 93.73%, and an 8th place puts him up to 99.97%, any higher placement locks him in at 100%.

The other players fighting for Blizzcon Chances at DreamHack Stockholm are Fantasy, Dark, Hyun, and ForGG.

Fantasy is currently in 16th place in WCS standings with 2900 WCS Points, he can make it without gaining additional points as long as Dark, Hyun, Dear, or ForGG don’t pass him, which means 29.15% if Fantasy gets 32nd or worse. A 4th place puts Fantasy at 84.68%.

Dark needs at least a 16th place, which would put him at 35.44%. A 2nd place would put him at 92.14%, and a 1st locks him in at 100%.

Hyun needs at least a 4th place, but that would only give him 10.23% Blizzcon Chances. A 2nd place would put Hyun at 34.44%, and a 1st place at 86.68%. If Hyun does win, he can still be knocked out if 2 out of sOs/Dear/Fantasy/Dark pass him.

ForGG must get at least 2nd place, which would put him at 24.03%, and a 1st place puts him at 80.23%. If ForGG wins then he has to worry about the same thing Hyun would, 2 players out of sOs/Dear/Fantasy/Dark passing him.

And let’s not forget about Dear, who would be 100% with winning GSL, or 0% with anything less.

As far as the final standings for WCS points, we already have a few seeds locked in, and some close to being locked in. herO at #1, Maru at #2, and Parting at #3 are all locked in already. Life at #4, Polt at #11, Zest at #12, and Lilbow at #13 are all above 70% chances.

Here are the current 10 most likely matches for the first round of the WCS Global Finals.

Life vs Lilbow has a 59.71% chance for the first round.

Polt vs Hydra has a 47.51% chance for the first round.

PartinG vs Rogue has a 44.68% chance for the first round.

Dream vs Classic has a 44.3% chance for the first round.

Maru vs Rogue has a 42.83% chance for the first round.

Maru vs sOs has a 39.31% chance for the first round.

Rain vs Polt has a 37.54% chance for the first round.

herO vs FanTaSy has a 35.64% chance for the first round.

Life vs Zest has a 29.89% chance for the first round.

INnoVation vs ByuL has a 28.93% chance for the first round.

Of course Dreamhack will have a big effect on these. Let’s look at some examples.

If sOs wins Dreamhack, then he’s likely to face Hydra (at a 50.01% chance), instead of Maru or herO. Also Parting vs Lilbow would be locked in at 100%. Life vs Zest and Maru vs Rogue would both be around 75%.

If sOs gets 2nd he’s likely to face Life. If he gets 4th then he’s likely to face Parting.

If Fantasy wins, then he’s likely to face Life (75.41%) instead of herO. Parting vs Lilbow would be nearly locked in at 94.84%. Life vs Fantasy would be a 75.41% chance. Maru vs Rogue, sOs vs herO, and Polt vs Hydra would all be around 58% to 50%.

If Fantasy gets 2nd in Dreamhack, then he’s likely to face Parting or Maru.

If Hyun, Dark, or ForGG wins, then Life vs Lilbow is around a 75% chance.

If Hyun wins then he’s likely to face herO (52.08%) or Maru (34.6%). Parting vs Rogue, Hyun vs herO, and Polt vs Hydra would be around 55% to 50%.

If Dark wins then he’s very likely to face Parting (94.63%) instead of herO. Maru vs Rogue and sOs vs herO would both be around 53%. IF Dark gets 2nd then he’s likely to face Maru.

If ForGG wins then he’s likely to face herO (45.59%) or Maru (34.64%). Parting vs Rogue and Polt vs Hydra would be around 55% to 50%.

If Rain wins then we can see that his chances of facing Lilbow (75.35%) go up significantly instead of Polt or Zest. Life vs Zest and Rain vs Lilbow would be around 80% to 75%. Parting vs Rogue, Maru vs sOs, and Dream vs Hydra would be around 55% to 45%.

And then if someone not going to Blizzcon wins, such as Solar, then Life vs Lilbow would be a 74.93% chance. Parting vs Rogue, Polt vs Hydra, and Maru vs sOs would be about 55% to 49%. Dream vs Classic, herO vs Fantasy, and Rain vs Polt would be about 45% to 42%. Maru vs Rogue, Innovation vs Zest, and Innovation vs Byul would be about 39% to 28%.

DreamHack and the GSL semifinals between Dear and ByuL both kick off at 2:30 am PDT on Thursday, September 24th, so we’re going to see the field narrowed down very quickly this week. DreamHack will have its finale at 1:30 pm PDT on Friday, September 25th, if you want to tune in and see if ForGG or HyuN went all the way. DreamHack and GSL are the last opportunities for WCS Points before Blizzcon, so don’t miss them!

After Dreamhack is complete, all that will be left is the GSL finals, and there will only 2 possible brackets for the WCS Global Finals! Look out for my next article where I’ll be covering that.

Be sure to check the website for very frequent updates, the FAQ, and the fantasy league WCS Wars!

To get automatically generated checkups that are constantly updated, I have created the Checkup page on WCS Predictor.

Also here’s my discussion thread on Team Liquid.

posts.title: BlizzCon Opening Week – October 28 to November 1
posts.title_plain: BlizzCon Opening Week – October 28 to November 1
posts.content:
Last year, we needed an extra weekend to contain all the World Championship eSports around BlizzCon—this year, we need an extra week!

The 2015 World Championships for Heroes of the Storm, Hearthstone, and World of Warcraft, along with the StarCraft II WCS Global Finals, will take place October 28–November 1 during an epic BlizzCon Opening Week event—broadcast live online from the ESL Studios in Burbank, CA.

BlizzCon Opening Week will host more than 100 elite eSports players from across the globe, all battling for the opportunity to be crowned World Champion at BlizzCon 2015 this November 6–7. You won’t want to miss the action, and we’ll have plenty of streaming options available on BlizzCon.com for each game.

Wondering which matches will be played at BlizzCon Opening Week? We’ve broken down the schedule for each game below:

Hearthstone World Championship

Schedule: October 28–31, starting at 9 a.m. PDT
Number of Players: 16
Prize Pool: $250,000
Matches: The Hearthstone World Championship kicks off with four groups of four players vying against each other in a dual-elimination format. Match 1 of each group will take place October 28, with Match 2 and the first eliminations taking place on October 29. On October 30–31, each match will advance one player to BlizzCon as the contenders make their way through the winners matches and decider matches of each group.

Heroes of the Storm World Championship

Schedule: October 28, starting at 1:30 p.m. PDT
Number of Players: 8 teams (5 players per team)
Prize Pool: $500,000
Matches: The Heroes of the Storm World Championship features two dual-tournament groups in the first round. No teams will be eliminated during BlizzCon Opening Week, but each team will get to show the world what they’re made of in these initial matches.

World of Warcraft Arena World Championship

Schedule: October 30–31, starting at 1:30 p.m. PDT
Number of Players: 8 teams (4 players per team)
Prize Pool: $250,000
Matches: Each of the two dual-tournament groups in the Round of 8 will compete October 30–31. Two teams will advance to the Round of 4 bracket (being played at BlizzCon) based on the results of these matches, while the other two Round of 4 teams will be determined at BlizzCon.

StarCraft II World Championship Series Global Finals

Schedule: November 1, starting at 10 a.m. PST
Number of Players: 16
Prize Pool: $250,000
Matches: The Global Finals will follow last year’s tried-and-true format. The top 16 players in the WCS Global Standings will be seeded into a single-elimination bracket, and all matches of the Round of 16 bracket will take place November 1. Eight of the 16 players will then advance to the Round of 8 matches at BlizzCon.

Once BlizzCon Opening Week’s wrapped, you’ll be able to watch coverage of the BlizzCon opening ceremony and all of the StarCraft II, Hearthstone, World of Warcraft, and Heroes of the Storm matches taking place at BlizzCon for free in HD at www.blizzcon.com. The StarCraft II finals will also be available to watch via the official WCS website.
posts.excerpt: Last year, we needed an extra weekend to contain all the World Championship eSports around BlizzCon—this year, we need an extra week! The 2015 World Championships for Heroes of the Storm, Hearthstone, and World of Warcraft, along with the StarCraft II WCS Global Finals, will take place October 28–November 1 during an epic BlizzCon Opening [...]

posts.title: 15 Koreans and Lilbow
posts.content:
If you didn’t read my previous articles, these stats are calculated by WCS Predictor, which simulates every match in every tournament that gives WCS Points millions of times. Blizzcon Chances are the chances to qualify in the top 16 for Blizzcon, as rated by WCS Predictor.

Last weekend with the WCS Playoffs finishing, we had the first foreigner since Naniwa qualify (nearly 100%, more on that later) for Blizzcon! Lilbow went from 21.63% Blizzcon Chances up to now 99.9992% with winning WCS over Mana. We also had a bunch of people go down recently with a bunch of eliminations mostly due to Lilbow and the WCS Playoffs.

Eliminations

MaNa went down by 0.66%, going from 0.66% to 0%

Petraeus went down by 0.11%, going from 0.11% to 0%

GunGFuBanDa went down by 0.02%, going from 0.02% to 0%

Big Drops

Dark went down by 28.51%, going from 31.59% to 3.09%

ForGG went down by 16.89%, going from 17.6% to 0.71%

FanTaSy went down by 15.98%, going from 88.32% to 72.34%

GuMiho went down by 6.25%, going from 16.84% to 10.59%

HyuN went down by 4.55%, going from 15.38% to 10.82%

sOs went down by 4.43%, going from 97.33% to 92.9%

TY went down by 0.41%, going from 1.13% to 0.72%

Stats went down by 0.25%, going from 0.57% to 0.32%

Almost Guaranteed

There are some situations where Lilbow doesn’t make it to Blizzcon, including a possible tie or even 3 way tie, but it’s very unlikely and Lilbow still has a 99.9992% chance to qualify for Blizzcon.

The following things must ALL happen in order for Lilbow to not make Blizzcon.

1. Fantasy wins DreamHack Stockholm.

2. sOs gets 2nd place in DreamHack Stockholm. sOs is not yet confirmed going to DreamHack, we may find out soon that he is not going and this would put Lilbow at 100% Blizzcon Chances.

3. Lilbow does not win any points from DreamHack Stockholm. It seems he will probably not attend.

4. Rogue gets 4th or 2nd place in GSL. 4th place with no points from DreamHack would make him tied with Lilbow.

5. EITHER: Gumiho wins GSL which would put him tied with Lilbow; OR Dear wins GSL AND gets at least 8th place in DreamHack Stockholm.

Although, unless GSL changes their schedule to accommodate, it would be impossible to play in the GSL semifinals and go to DreamHack, which means Dear would not be able to pass or tie Lilbow, and Rogue would only tie with Lilbow if he gets 4th in GSL.

So with those conditions, we can end up in one of these situtations.

1. No tie, Lilbow is #17

2. Tie between Lilbow and Rogue

3. Tie between Gumiho and Lilbow

4. Tie between Gumiho, Rogue, and Lilbow, with 2 winners of the tie breaker match going to Blizzcon and the single loser out

Here is a dump from WCS Predictor of situations where Lilbow does not qualify for Blizzcon, often involving him losing tie breaker matches

Keep in mind this is all very unlikely, Lilbow has a 99.9992% chance of making Blizzcon. I know I’d be hyped for a 3 way tie breaker for Blizzcon!

Here are Lilbow’s current most likely first round opponents for the WCS Global Finals.

Lilbow vs Maru has a 31.92% chance for the first round.

Lilbow vs Life has a 30.45% chance for the first round.

Lilbow vs PartinG has a 26.25% chance for the first round.

Lilbow vs ByuL has a 6.05% chance for the first round.

Lilbow vs Classic has a 2.43% chance for the first round.

Lilbow vs Hydra has a 1.2% chance for the first round.

Checkup Before GSL Quarterfinals

Let’s do a checkup of all the players still in the running for Blizzcon. We are now down to only 23 players above 0% Blizzcon Chances. Keep in mind that playing in the GSL semifinals and going to DreamHack Stockholm cannot happen unless GSL adjusts their schedule for players wanting to do both.

Secured Players – 100% Blizzcon Chances – 12 Players

herO 100% with 7,150 WCS Points.

PartinG 100% with 5,850 WCS Points.

Maru 100% with 5,750 WCS Points.

Life 100% with 5,475 WCS Points.

Hydra 100% with 5,000 WCS Points.

Rain 100% with 4,925 WCS Points.

Classic 100% with 4,550 WCS Points.

ByuL 100% with 4,325 WCS Points.

Dream 100% with 4,275 WCS Points.

INnoVation 100% with 3,925 WCS Points.

Polt 100% with 3,875 WCS Points.

Zest 100% with 3,675 WCS Points.

Nearly Secured Players – Over 95% – 2 Players

Lilbow 99.99% with 3,625 WCS Points.

Rogue 99.97% with 3,325 WCS Points.

Over 20% – 2 Players

sOs 92.9% with 3,150 WCS Points.

sOs has plenty of points, he just has a few players to be worried about passing him. If Dark or Fantasy makes top 4 in DreamHack; or if ForGG, Hyun, or TY wins DreamHack; then sOs drops to around 67%. If Dear or Gumiho wins GSL, then sOs falls to about 70%.

FanTaSy 72.34% with 2,900 WCS Points.

If Fantasy gets 8th in DreamHack then he goes up to 82.81%, however he would still have to worry about players passing him, a 4th place would be much safer at 98.19%. If Fantasy does get 8th place and Hyun, ForGG, TY, or Dark wins DreamHack, then Fantasy falls down to about 33%. If Fantasy gets 8th in DreamHack and Gumiho or Dear wins GSL, then Fantasy falls to about 36%.

Over 5% – 3 Players

HyuN 10.82% with 2,525 WCS Points.

To get nearly secured HyuN needs to win DreamHack Stockholm, which would put him at 97.53%. An 8th place would put him at 0%, 4th place at 20.75%, and a 2nd place at 49.41%. But if TY, Dark, Stats, ForGG, or Fantasy wins DreamHack then HyuN cannot qualify for Blizzcon.

GuMiho 10.59% with 2,225 WCS Points.

If Gumiho wins GSL then he is nearly secured at 99.99%. If he gets 2nd place in GSL, then he would need at least a 16th place in DreamHack to go with it to have any chance, putting him at 44.31%, but again that’s unlikely due to the scheduling. If he gets 8th in GSL then the schedule should allow him the possiblity of going to DreamHack, he would need to win DreamHack to have any chance, and it would put him at 47.57%.

Dear 8.52% with 2,125 WCS Points.

If Dear does not go to DreamHack, then he must win GSL, which would put him at 99.97%. If Dear manages to get 4th in GSL and win DreamHack then he goes up to 95.93%. A 2nd place in both GSL and DreamHack puts Dear at 99.18%.

Over 0% – 4 Players

Dark 3.09% with 2,800 WCS Points.

Dark is not yet confirmed as going to DreamHack, but he needs to at least get a 16th place there to have any chance, which would put him at 37.34%. 4th place would put him at 94.03%.

TY 0.72% with 2,500 WCS Points.

TY needs to get at least 2nd place at DreamHack, that would put him at 39.43%. 1st place would put him at 96.55%.

ForGG 0.71% with 2,425 WCS Points.

ForGG is in a similar spot as TY, he needs at least a 2nd place in DreamHack to get 38.65%, and a 1st place would put him at 96.44%.

Stats 0.32% with 2,350 WCS Points.

Stats needs to win DreamHack to have any chance at Blizzcon, this would put him at 60.63%. If Fantasy gets 8th place in DreamHack then Blizzcon is impossible for Stats.

Be sure to check the website for very frequent updates, the FAQ, and the fantasy league WCS Wars!

To get automatically generated checkups that are constantly updated, I have created the Checkup page on WCS Predictor.

Also here’s my discussion thread on Team Liquid!
